questions.neutral: Did you make it through the noise?

hobby.message: Any luck fixing the old typewriter?
Still dodging towers with those drones?
Found any new political literature lately?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: Yes. It was loud, but I managed.
Spent the time inside, working on something quiet.
I restore old typewriters. Calms the nerves.
Found it better than following the news lately.
Got through as well as anyone, I suppose.
Kept to my apartment, away from the windows.
Restored a Remington from the archives—my odd little hobby.
Hard to concentrate with all the recent disturbances.
Noise can't touch a machine built to last.
Yes, barely heard myself think. City's been uneasy.
I kept to my workbench—restoring typewriters, as usual for me.
Always liked the mechanics, the rhythm of the keys.
After the recent outages, more people want old machines repaired.
Seems folks rediscover paper when systems go down.
Not a bad way to spend a loud night.
Got through it, thanks to stubbornness and thick walls.
Was fixing a Swiss Hermes—part of my antique typewriter project.
Strange, how relevant my hobby’s become with these digital disruptions.
Power flickered, but a typewriter doesn’t care about outages.
Some neighbors are asking for repairs, sudden interest in ink and paper.
I even helped a student draft something for his zone board—by hand, imagine.
Old habits return when new ones break.
Made it, though I had to finish in candlelight by the end.
I was restoring a Lettera 22, hoping the blackouts wouldn't ruin the ribbon.
You know, typewriters were just nostalgia until the BCI shutdown started affecting basic services.
Now I’m helping neighbors send messages—safe from prying models.
Hadn’t used my carbon sheets in years, but people need discreet copies.
Feels like my old skills matter again—the city’s systems aren’t the only legacy here.
Sometimes I log what’s happening, by hand, in case the history vanishes online.
Suppose we adapt. Machines survive, and so do we.
hobby_answer: Yes. Picked up an Underwood from a neighbor. Needed minor repairs.
Not much else worth saying. Work keeps me busy enough.
Free zone outages make parts hard to find these days.
Keep things simple. No need to attract attention.
People seem more interested in old tools than they used to.
That's right, an old Underwood. Just a simple cleaning job.
Parts are scarce with everything shut down outside digital-free zones.
Strange how typewriters have become useful again, isn't it?
Last week someone left a manual at my door.
I don't advertise — too much interest from the wrong people.
Events outside have made folk nostalgic for paper, or maybe just wary.
Yes, a Remington this time. It's relaxing work for my hands.
Funny how demand for ribbons and spare keys is up since the blackouts.
Someone even traded instructions for using them during the latest system outage.
Lately, lots of requests for repairs—people worry digital traces might follow them.
Makes me wonder if the free zones will keep relying on analog tools.
Hard to say if it's truly safe, but old habits serve well now.
Feels like the city's rediscovering slow, careful craftsmanship.
New typewriter on the bench, yes—a battered Erika in dire need of TLC.
With the system flaring up and data floods everywhere, folks want reliable tools.
Collected a stack of typed notices just last night—felt like 1986 again.
People come by after outages, hoping for something untraceable, something tangible.
I've even started keeping carbon copies again, just in case.
Sometimes, a hand-typed note says what encrypted messages can't—quiet, personal.
The rhythm of cleaning typebars is a kind of meditation for me.
Odd, but these old machines feel more honest than anything digital now.
Ah, yes—the Erika Model 5, rescued after the blackout last week.
I’ve been fixing it in the evenings—helps pass the hours when news is uncertain.
After the Directorate tried to sabotage free zones, leaflets started arriving everywhere—typed, naturally.
Seems like everyone wants their own words off the grid, away from BCI prying.
Reminds me of council days—back when a memotype could quietly change everything.
I even found myself typing for neighbors, old contacts too nervous to sign their own names.
Handwritten drafts, carbon-paper copies—I keep them hidden, just in case.
There’s a strange comfort in restoring order to battered keys, when nothing else makes sense.
Honestly, I trust these machines more than any ‘trusted system’ I ever served.
